security: This collection of memoranda discusses the release of CIA officer names, cryptonyms, country designators, and action indicators in JFK assassination records. The documents reveal concerns about protecting covert employees, their cover mechanisms, and intelligence operations. They also highlight the need to balance transparency with the safety and privacy of individuals involved in sensitive activities. Direct quotes include: 'We are concerned about individuals that continue to be dependent on particular cover legends' and 'if a person worked for the CIA it should be known.' Sharing details on cover mechanisms, personnel, and ongoing intelligence operations could pose risks to both individuals and national security.
summary: These memoranda discuss the CIA's position on releasing information related to the JFK assassination records, focusing on protecting covert employees' identities, cover mechanisms, and ongoing intelligence operations, while balancing transparency with security concerns.
summary_one_paragraph: This collection of memoranda from 1995 to 1997 details discussions between the CIA's Historical Review Group (HRG), the Directorate of Operations (DO), the Office of General Counsel (OGC), and the Assassination Records Review Board (ARRB) regarding the release of CIA officer names, cryptonyms, and other sensitive information related to the JFK assassination records; the documents highlight the Agency's efforts to protect covert employees, their cover mechanisms, and ongoing intelligence operations, while attempting to cooperate with the ARRB's review process and address concerns about transparency and the public interest.
title: Memoranda Regarding the Release of CIA Information in JFK Assassination Records
recipient: Various (J. Barry Harrelson, Jeremy Gunn, Chief/HRG, Review Board, etc.)
sender: Bryant Rogers, Barry Harrelson, Fredrick C. Wickham, Jr., David G. Marwell, John F. Pereira, T. Jeremy Gunn, Linda C. Cipriani, Gary M. Breneman, Barry Harrelson
